thread.title: Pacers Forward Glenn Robinson III Wins 2017 NBA All-Star Dunk Contest
thread.title_full: Pacers Forward Glenn Robinson III Wins 2017 NBA All-Star Dunk Contest

author: Kyle Neubeck
title: Pacers Forward Glenn Robinson III Wins 2017 NBA All-Star Dunk Contest
text:
Kyle is a freelance writer based out of Philadelphia. Follow him here . Feb 19, 2017 Tweet Media via Twitter Aaron Gordon was the runaway favorite in the 2017 NBA All-Star Dunk Contest, and the Orlando Magic forward blew his golden opportunity. After losing in heartbreaking fashion to Minnesota's Zach LaVine last year, Gordon bombed out in the first round of the competition, making way for Pacers forward Glenn Robinson III to take home the crown. It was a war of attrition more than anything. The 2017 Dunk Contest was plagued with bad misses, high-wire acts that misfired, and barely-made dunks that wouldn't cut it in a D-League competition, let alone in the main event. Robinson III sprinkled in a couple of flashy finishes, but it wasn't quite enough to make up for a listless night overall. We missed you, Zach LaVine. First Round DeAndre Jordan incorporated DJ Khaled and social media into his first attempt, performing what might be the very first Snapchat dunk in contest history. 
DJ over DJ... pic.twitter.com/ W9QJ9Hc0of — Complex Sports ( @ComplexSports ) February 19, 2017 Glenn Robinson III announced his arrival on the scene with authority, executing a sick one-handed flush over a pair of piggybacked men. 
Glenn Robinson III is unreal pic.twitter.com/ D7PBEtdNAC — Complex Sports ( @ComplexSports ) February 19, 2017 Derrick Jones Jr., the biggest unknown in the competition, jumped over four people—including the Suns Gorilla!—but had points deducted after he pushed off of the last man in the line to get it done. 
. @TheRea1DJones showed off his  # VerizonDunk Receives 45 PTS for first dunk pic.twitter.com/ sKWJfArxB0 — NBA TV ( @NBATV ) February 19, 2017 In the sponsored portion of the competition, Aaron Gordon had some help from an Intel drone on his first attempt. But there was a bit of trouble with the execution, and—perhaps in a bit of pay-for-play shenanigans—Gordon got a fourth chance to complete the dunk. 
The world's first official " SlamDrone ". February 18, 2017. 8: 59pm CT. @Double0AG @intel @NBAAllStar pic.twitter.com/ giIyPbOhrq Cool concept, meh execution. The judges responded accordingly, handing Gordon the lowest score of the opening round with a 38. Social media wasn't too crazy about it either: 
THE ROBOTS HAVE TURNED ON US! — Matt Dollinger ( @matt_dollinger ) February 19, 2017 
I'll be honest, I did not expect to hear the phrase "reload the drone" during a dunk contest. — Brian Grubb ( @briancgrubb ) February 19, 2017 
2017: the NBA dunk contest as dystopian future filled with surveillance drones and DJ Khaled as America's most complete artist. — Otto Von Biz Markie ( @Passionweiss ) February 19, 2017 Second Round Gordon failed to complete his second attempt, leaving fans wondering what might have been if he had shown up to the competition healthy. The other big name was just as forgetful; Jordan's second dunk was technically impressive, but the finish left a lot to be desired: — NBA on TNT ( @NBAonTNT ) February 19, 2017 Thankfully, Jones Jr. woke the crowd up from its slumber with some assistance from Suns teammate Devin Booker. He went off the side of the glass with a through-the-legs windmill, turning in the best second attempt for the field. 
"This young man came to play tonight." @TheRea1DJones is putting on a show!  # VerizonDunk pic.twitter.com/ dkF5im9blp — NBA on TNT ( @NBAonTNT ) February 19, 2017 Virtually unknown to a lot of the NBA world prior to the dunk contest, Jones Jr. had people caping for him left and right after that one: 
DJJR dont wanna go back to the D-League
